com.badlogic.gdx
Interface Application

All Known Implementing Classes:
AndroidApplication, JoglApplication
public interface Application

An Application wraps all features related to game development. This includes the graphics system, the audio system, file i/o as well as input from devices such as the keyboard, the mouse or a touch screen. Mouse and touch screen are handled transparently.

For now there's two implementations of the Application interface. One is used on desktop PCs and is called JoglApplication. The other is used on Android devices and is called AndroidApplication. The JoglApplication wraps OpenGL for desktop PCs via Jogl. The AndroidApplication wraps a GLSurfaceView and is derived from the Android class Activity.

A basic application starts by instantiating either a JoglApplication or an AndroidApplication. After the instantiation a RenderListener has to be registered with the Application. A RenderListener is called on three events: when it is created RenderListener.setup() is called, during rendering RenderListener.render() is called repeatedly and when the RenderListener is unregistered or the application is destroyed RenderListener.dispose() is called.

The Application interface offers a couple of methods in order to keep things plattform independant. These methods are grouped into several areas: graphics, sound, input and file i/o.

The graphics method are modeled after OpenGL. There's methods for matrix stack manipulation, setting render states like blending, culling and so on, methods for creating and enabling light sources and more. Browse through the method summary of this class to get more information. Note that not all of OpenGL's functionality is exposed. For example there's no way to set materials for lighting, by default color material is used. Apart from these methods that essentially wrap OpenGL calls there's also methods to create graphics related resources. The following paragraphs describe the 4 graphics related resources briefly.

A Mesh encapsulates all geometry business you have to deal with in your game. Meshes can only be created by an Application by calling one of the Application.newMesh() methods. Note that you are yourself responsible to fee all resources associated with a mesh by calling a mesh's Mesh.dispose() Method.

A Texture encapsulates a single OpenGL texture. As with Meshes you can only create a Texture via an Application by calling Application.newTexture(). You also have to take care of releasing all resources of a texture by calling its Texture.dispose() method when you're done.

A Font encapsulates a font to be used to render text in OpenGL. Internally it holds a texture with the glyphs used by all texts that are created by this Font. You can only create a Font by calling one of the Application.newFont() methods. When you are done using a Font you have to release its resources via a call to Font.dispose().

A Pixmap is a plattform agnostic way of working with bitmaps. Pixmaps can only be created by an Application via a call to Application.newPixmap(). You can draw to pixmaps and even draw pixmaps to textures for some nice effects.

To summarize: the Application acts as a factory for graphic resources. Once you have obtained such a resource its up to you to handle releasing all system resources it encapsulates by calling the resource's dispose() method. See the respective interface documentation for more information.

Apart from being a resource factory an Application also wraps OpenGL functionality. This includes matrix stack manipulation, state changes and so on. Refer to the method documentations of this class for more information. Not all of OpenGLs functionality is wrapped of course. Feel free to extend this but make sure that your additions work on the PC as well as on Android!

Obtaining user input can be done in two ways, either via polling or by registering an Application.TextInputListener which follows the event based paradigm.

Polling is done via the methods Application.isKeyPressed() for checking the state of keys, Application.getX() and Application.getY() for checking the mouse or touch position, Application.isPressed() for checking wheter any mouse button was pressed or the screen is touched and Application.getAccelerometerX(), Application.getAccelerometerY() and Application.getAccelerometerZ() to get the state of the 3-axis accelerometer if one is available. Note that it is not possible at the moment to check for a concrete mouse button (left, right, middle) as this is not supported on Android devices. Also, checking for keys is currently not fully implemented as there's no enum yet that encapsulates all the possible keys for both plattforms. This will be added in a later version FIXME

When registering an Application.TextInputListener the application will relay input events to this InputListener in a synchronous way. This means that the methods of the registered InputListener will be called in the rendering thread of the application which also calls the RenderListener. Internally events are queued and processed upon each rendering of a frame. This allows you to forget about thread synchronization issues between the UI and your RenderListener which operates in a seperate rendering thread.

For getting text input form the user a special method exists called Application.getTextInput() which creates a plattform specific text input dialog box for the user to use. A callback you specify will be called synchronously to you rendering thread once input has finished.

Audio is not supported 100% at the moment. FIXME You can play small sound effects you have loaded via the Application.newSound() method easily or do your own sound mixing with a call to Application.getAudioDevice() which lets you feed PCM data to the audio device directly. Currently this only supports output of 44.1khz mono PCM data. This will change in the near future. Another method called Application.newMusic() will be introduced that allows streaming and playback of normal audio files.

File I/O methods provided by the Application interface allow you to get access to assets and the SD card on Android. To map this to the desktop the assets directory is assumed to be the directory the application was started from. To simulate reading and writting to and form an SD card on the desktop the current users home directory is used. See the respective methods of this interface for more information.

Author:
mzechner

Method Detail

addRenderListener

void addRenderListener(RenderListener listener)
Adds a RenderListener to this application. The listener's setup method is called once before the render method is invoked. The render method is called as long as the listener is registered with the application. Upon application shutdown the dispose method is called.

Parameters:
listener - The listener to add.

removeRenderListener

void removeRenderListener(RenderListener listener)
Removes the RenderListener from this application. The listener's dispose method is called.

Parameters:
listener - The listener to remove.

addInputListener

void addInputListener(InputListener listener)
Adds an Application.TextInputListener to this application. The order input listeners are added is the same as the order in which they are accessed. If an input listener signals that it processed the event the event is not passed to the other listeners in the chain.

Parameters:
listener - The listener

removeInputListener

void removeInputListener(InputListener listener)
Removes the Application.TextInputListener from this application.

Parameters:
listener - The listener

addCloseListener

void addCloseListener(Application.CloseListener listener)
Adds a close listener.

Parameters:
listener - The listener

removeCloseListener

void removeCloseListener(Application.CloseListener listener)
Removes a close listener

Parameters:
listener - The listener

listResourceFiles

java.lang.String[] listResourceFiles(java.lang.String directory)
                                     throws java.io.IOException
Lists the files and directories in the given directory. The directory is relative to the resource directory which is platform dependent. On Android the directory given is relative to the assets directory, on the PC it is relative to the root directory of the application.

Parameters:
directory - The directory to list.
Returns:
An array of files and directories with names relative to the resource directory
Throws:
java.io.IOException

Parameters:
file - The file
Returns:
The input stream
Throws:
java.io.IOException

newTexture

Texture newTexture(java.lang.String file,
                   Application.TextureFilter minFilter,
                   Application.TextureFilter magFilter,
                   Application.TextureWrap uWrap,
                   Application.TextureWrap vWrap)
Loads the texture from the given file which points to an image. The file is relative to the assets directory on Android and relative to the applications directory on the PC. The parameters specify the textures minification and magnification filters as well as the texture wrap mode in u and v.

Parameters:
string - The file name
minFilter - The minification filter
magFilter - The magnification filter
uWrap - The wrap in u
vWrap - The wrap in v
Returns:

newTexture

Texture newTexture(java.io.InputStream in,
                   Application.TextureFilter minFiler,
                   Application.TextureFilter maxFilter,
                   Application.TextureWrap uWrap,
                   Application.TextureWrap vWrap)
Creates a new texture from the given InputStream which points to an image. The InputSteam is not closed. The parameters specify the textures minification and magnification filters as well as the texture wrap mode in u and v.

Parameters:
in - The inputstream
minFiler - The minification filter
maxFilter - The magnification filter
uWrap - The texture wrap in u
vWrap - The texture wrap in v
Returns:
The texture

newTexture

Texture newTexture(int width,
                   int height,
                   Application.TextureFilter minFilter,
                   Application.TextureFilter maxFilter,
                   Application.TextureWrap uWrap,
                   Application.TextureWrap vWrap)
Creates a new blank texture with the given dimensions in pixels. The parameters specify the textures minification and magnification filters as well as the texture wrap mode in u and v.

Parameters:
width - The width of the texture
height - The height of the texture
minFiler - The minification filter
maxFilter - The magnification filter
uWrap - The texture wrap in u
vWrap - The texture wrap in v
Returns:
The texture

newTexture

Texture newTexture(Pixmap pixmap,
                   Application.TextureFilter minFilter,
                   Application.TextureFilter maxFilter,
                   Application.TextureWrap uWrap,
                   Application.TextureWrap vwrap)
Creates a texture from the specified Pixmap. Tries to create a texture with the format of the pixmap. The parameters specify the textures minification and magnification filters as well as the texture wrap mode in u and v. Only power of two textures are supported. Behaviour for none power of two textures is not specified.

Parameters:
pixmap - The pixmap.
minFilter - The minification filter.
maxFilter - The magnification filter.
uWrap - The wrap in u.
vwrap - The wrap in v.
Returns:
The texture.

             boolean hasColors,
             boolean hasNormals,
             boolean hasUV,
             boolean hasIndices,
             int maxIndices,
             boolean isStatic)
Creates a new empty Mesh with the given characteristics.

Parameters:
numVertices - The maximum number of vertices
hasColors - Wheter the mesh has colors
hasNormals - Wheter the mesh has normals
hasUV - Wheter the mesh has texture coordinates
hasIndices - Wheter the mesh has indices
numIndices - The maximum number of indices
isStatic - Wheter the mesh is static or not.
Returns:
The mesh

newFontFromFile

Font newFontFromFile(java.lang.String file,
                     int size,
                     Application.FontStyle style)
Returns a font object for the attributes specified loaded from the given file. The loading is done internally with the getInputStream method so the file path is relative to the applications directory on the PC and relative to the assets directory on Android.

Parameters:
file - The file to load the font from
size - The size of the font in pixels
style - The style of the font
Returns:
The font object

setMatrixMode

void setMatrixMode(Application.MatrixMode mode)
Sets the matrix mode. This equivalent to the OpenGL function glSetMatrixMode.

Parameters:
mode - The matrix mode

translate

void translate(float x,
               float y,
               float z)
Multiplies the current matrix on the current matrix stack with a translation matrix constructed from the arguments. This equivalent to the OpenGL function glTranslatef.

Parameters:
x - Translation in x
y - Translation in y
z - Translation in z

scale

void scale(float x,
           float y,
           float z)
Multiplies the current matrix on the current matrix stack with the scale matrix constructed from the arguments This equivalent to the OpenGL function glScalef.

Parameters:
x - Scale in x
y - Scale in y
z - Scale in z

rotate

void rotate(float angle,
            float x,
            float y,
            float z)
Multiplies the current matrix on the current matrix stack with the rotation matrix constructed from the arguments This equivalent to the OpenGL function glRotatef.

Parameters:
angle - the angle in degrees
x - The rotation axis x component
y - The rotation axis y component
z - The rotation axis z component

loadIdentity

void loadIdentity()
Loads an identity matrix. This equivalent to the OpenGL function glLoadIdentity.

loadMatrix

void loadMatrix(float[] matrix)
Loads a 4x4 matrix in column major order to the current matrix on the current matrix stack. This equivalent to the OpenGL function glLoadMatrix.

Parameters:
matrix - The matrix

multMatrix

void multMatrix(float[] matrix)
Multiplies the current Matrix on the current matrix stack with the given matrix. The given matrix must be given in column major order. This equivalent to the OpenGL function glMultMatrix.

Parameters:
matrix - The matrix

pushMatrix

void pushMatrix()
Pushes the current matrix. This equivalent to the OpenGL function glPushMatrix.

popMatrix

void popMatrix()
Pops the current matrix. This equivalent to the OpenGL function glPopMatrix.

clear

void clear(boolean color,
           boolean depth,
           boolean stencil)
Clears the buffers for which the flag is set to true. Uses the current clear color set by Application.clearColor() and the OpenGL default values for the depth buffer and stencil buffer. FIXME should also be able to specify depth and stencil clear value

Parameters:
color - clear the color (frame) buffer
depth - clear the depth buffer
stencil - clear the stencil buffer (not supported yet)

                float a)
Sets the clear color.

Parameters:
r - Red component
g - Green component
b - Blue component
a - Alpha component

Parameters:

z - Z component

enable

void enable(Application.RenderState state)
Enables the given Application.RenderState. This is equivalent to glEnable. A couple of convenience settings are performed for a vew RenderStates:
  • RenderState.Lighting will also enable GL_COLOR_MATERIAL
  • RenderState.DepthTest will also call glDepthMask( true )
  • RenderState.AlphaTest will also call gl.glAlphaFunc( GL.GL_GREATER, 0.9f )

Parameters:
state - The render state to enable

disable

void disable(Application.RenderState state)
Disables the given Application.RenderState.
  • RenderState.DepthTest will also call glDepthMask( false )

Parameters:
state - The render state

setPointSize

void setPointSize(int width)
Sets the point size

Parameters:
width - in pixels

blendFunc

void blendFunc(Application.BlendFunc srcArg,
               Application.BlendFunc dstArg)
Sets the blend function. This is equal to glBlendFunc.

Parameters:
srcArg - The source argument
dstArg - The target argument

depthFunc

void depthFunc(Application.DepthFunc func)
Sets the depth function. This is equal to glDepthFunc.

Parameters:
func - The depth function

setCullMode

void setCullMode(Application.CullMode order)
Sets the culling winding order. This is equal to glCullFace.

Parameters:
order - The culling winding order.

setAmbientLight

void setAmbientLight(float r,
                     float g,
                     float b,
                     float a)
Sets the ambient light color. This is equal to calling gl.glLightModelfv( GL.GL_LIGHT_MODEL_AMBIENT, color, 0 ).

Parameters:
r - The red component
g - The green component
b - The blue component
a - The alpha component

setDirectionalLight

void setDirectionalLight(int light,
                         float x,
                         float y,
                         float z,
                         float r,
                         float g,
                         float b,
                         float a)
Sets the light to the given direction and color. It has to be enabled via enableLight. The direction has to be normalized. Sets the ambient and diffuse color of the directional light to the given color components. As oposed to the standard notion of OpenGL the light direction is really given as a direction and not as a negative direction as usual!

Parameters:
light - The number of the light source
x - The direction x component
y - The direction y component
z - The direction z component
r - The red component
g - The green component
b - The blue component
a - The alpha component

disableLight

void disableLight(int light)
Enables the given light. This is equal to glEnable( light ).

Parameters:
light - the light number

enableLight

void enableLight(int light)
Disables the light. This is equal to glDisable( light ).

Parameters:
light - The light number

flush

void flush()
makes sure that any rendering commands are executed. This is equal to calling glFinish.

wheter an accelerometer is available

The value of the accelerometer on its y-axis. ranges between [-10,10].

getAccelerometerZ

float getAccelerometerZ()
Returns:
The value of the accelerometer on its y-axis. ranges between [-10,10].

the mouse x position in screen coordinates. The screen origin is the top left corner.

the mouse x position in screen coordinates. The screen origin is the top left corner.

Returns:
The y-coordinate of the pointer

isPressed

boolean isPressed(int pointer)
Multitouch extension. Experimental.

Parameters:
pointer - the pointer index.
Returns:
Wheter the pointer is down or not.

isKeyPressed

boolean isKeyPressed(Application.Keys key)
Wheter the key is pressed.

Parameters:
key - The key.
Returns:
True or false.

getTextInput

void getTextInput(Application.TextInputListener listener,
                  java.lang.String title,
                  java.lang.String text)
System dependent method to input a string of text. A dialog box will be created with the given title and the given text as a message for the user. Once the dialog has been closed the provided Application.TextInputListener will be called in the rendering thread.

Parameters:
listener - The TextInputListener.
title - The title of the text input dialog.
text - The message presented to the user.

getDeltaTime

float getDeltaTime()
Returns:
the delta time in seconds to the previous frame.

log

void log(java.lang.String tag,
         java.lang.String message)
logs the given message with the given tag to some output (e.g. System.out, Log.d)

Parameters:
tag - The tag
message - the message

newSound

Sound newSound(java.lang.String file)
Creates a new Sound form a file. The file is given relative to the assets directory on Android and relative to the applications directory on the PC.

Parameters:
file - The file.
Returns:
The Sound instance.

getAudioDevice

AudioDevice getAudioDevice()
Returns:
the AudioDevice in 44100Hz, mono mode.

wheter we are on Android or not.
